questions.instructions:
Questions 1–7

Do the following statements agree with the information given in the reading passage?

Write TRUE if the statement agrees with the information, FALSE if the statement contradicts the information, or NOT GIVEN if there is no information on this.
questions.question: On Wednesdays the shortest class is Abdominal strengthening.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: TRUE. Check the Wednesday schedule - Abdominal strengthening (07:45-08:15) is 30 minutes, the shortest class that day.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! On Wednesdays, Abdominal strengthening runs from 07:45-08:15, which is 30 minutes - the shortest class that day.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: TRUE. On Wednesdays, Abdominal strengthening is 30 minutes (07:45-08:15), which is shorter than the other Wednesday classes.

questions.question: The class on Mondays which is open to private members only is held in the Indoor Sports Hall.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. The schedule doesn't provide any information about private member restrictions.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The schedule doesn't mention anything about private members or membership restrictions.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. There's no information about private members in the schedule.

questions.question: Only one of the Tuesday classes is held outside.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: TRUE. On Tuesdays, Jogging club is the only outdoor class (held on the Outdoor track).
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! On Tuesdays, only the Jogging club is held outside on the Outdoor track.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: TRUE. Looking at Tuesday's schedule, only Jogging club (Outdoor track) is held outside.

questions.question: The Aerobics and Tae Kwon Do classes are of the same duration.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: TRUE. Aerobics is 17:30-18:30 and Tae Kwon Do is 18:30-19:30, both are 60 minutes.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! Both Aerobics (17:30-18:30) and Tae Kwon Do (18:30-19:30) run for 60 minutes.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: TRUE. Both classes run for exactly one hour (60 minutes).

questions.question: There is only one class held on each weekday before midday.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: FALSE. Check the schedule - Thursdays have both Pilates (09:00-10:00) and Gym Circuit (12:00-13:00) before midday.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! On Thursdays there are two morning classes: Pilates (09:00-10:00) and Gym Circuit (12:00-13:00).
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: FALSE. Thursdays have two classes before midday: Pilates and Gym Circuit.

questions.question: No experience is required to attend the Yoga class held on Fridays.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. The schedule doesn't provide information about experience requirements for Yoga or any class.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The schedule doesn't mention experience requirements for any classes.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. There's no information about experience requirements in the schedule.

questions.question: There are fewer classes available during university holidays.
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: TRUE. The text explicitly says 'During university holidays, only selected classes operate.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text states 'During university holidays, only selected classes operate,' meaning fewer classes.
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: TRUE. The passage clearly states 'only selected classes operate' during holidays.

questions.instructions:
Questions 8–10

Choose the correct letter, A, B, C, or D.
questions.question: Members who upset other users of the leisure centre
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: C - will have their membership cancelled. The passage says 'The owners reserve the right to terminate membership for breaches of rules or offensive behaviour.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text states 'The owners reserve the right to terminate membership for breaches of rules or offensive behaviour.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: C - will have their membership cancelled. The rules state that the owners can terminate membership for offensive behaviour.

B. will be given a warning
C. will have their membership cancelled
D. will be reported to the Membership Secretary

questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. None of the options are mentioned in the text - there's no information about holding membership.

B. through arrangement with the manager

D. in cases of injury only

questions.question: Damage to members’ vehicles
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: C - is not the responsibility of the centre. The passage says 'The centre accepts no liability for loss or damage to vehicles.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text clearly states 'The centre accepts no liability for loss or damage to vehicles.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: C - is not the responsibility of the centre. The rules explicitly state 'The centre accepts no liability for loss or damage to vehicles.'

B. will be paid for by the centre if it is their fault
C. is not the responsibility of the centre
D. may result from staff negligence

questions.instructions:
Questions 11–14

Answer the questions below.

Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER from the passage for each answer.
questions.question: During what should you start looking at the dress code employees seem to be following?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: INTERVIEWS. The text states 'When attending interviews, observe what other employees are wearing.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text says 'When attending interviews, observe what other employees are wearing.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: INTERVIEWS. The passage advises to observe dress codes when attending interviews.

questions.question: What might men want to think about wearing or not wearing on the second day?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: A TIE. The text says men might reconsider wearing a tie if no one else wears one.
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text mentions 'Wearing a tie on the first day is fine, but it may be unnecessary if no one else is wearing one.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: A TIE. The passage discusses whether men need to wear a tie on the second day.

questions.question: Apart from being in the same office, what makes a colleague a useful guide for what to wear?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: SIMILAR ROLES. The text advises 'observing colleagues in similar roles is often the best guide.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The text states 'observing colleagues in similar roles is often the best guide.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: SIMILAR ROLES. The passage says to observe colleagues in similar roles.

questions.question: What type of company is introducing management uniforms?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is: LARGE CORPORATIONS. The passage says 'in large corporations, there has been a move towards...uniforms for management.'
questions.correct_feedback: Correct! The passage states 'especially in large corporations, there has been a move towards stricter dress codes, including uniforms for management.'
questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: LARGE CORPORATIONS. The text mentions large corporations are introducing management uniforms.

questions.incorrect_feedback: Incorrect. The correct answer is: NOT GIVEN. There's no information about the employment market in the passage.

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 1
reading_texts.content:
City University Gym – Term-time Weekday Schedule (Semesters 1 & 2)

Mondays & Wednesdays
Abdominal strengthening – 07:45–08:15 – Main Gym – Joanna
Gym Circuit – 12:00–13:00 – Main Gym – Steve
Five-a-side football – 12:00–13:00 – Outdoor pitch – Mark
Aerobics – 17:30–18:30 – Dance studio – Claire
Tae Kwon Do – 18:30–19:30 – Indoor sports hall – Kim

Tuesdays
Yoga – 08:00–09:00 – Indoor sports hall – Priya
Jogging club – 12:30–13:15 – Outdoor track – Staff
Basketball – 18:00–19:00 – Indoor sports hall – Alex

Thursdays
Pilates – 09:00–10:00 – Main Gym – Joanna
Gym Circuit – 12:00–13:00 – Main Gym – Steve
Badminton – 17:00–18:00 – Indoor sports hall – Staff

Fridays
Yoga – 10:00–11:00 – Indoor sports hall – Priya
Swimming – 16:00–17:00 – University pool – Staff

During university holidays, only selected classes operate.

Questions 1–7

[This is a closed question set.
Question type: TRUE / FALSE / NOT GIVEN.
There are 7 questions (1–7).
Answer options must be displayed as: TRUE, FALSE, NOT GIVEN.
All questions refer to Reading Text 1 only.]

On Wednesdays the shortest class is Abdominal strengthening.

The class on Mondays which is open to private members only is held in the Indoor Sports Hall.

Only one of the Tuesday classes is held outside.

The Aerobics and Tae Kwon Do classes are of the same duration.

There is only one class held on each weekday before midday.

No experience is required to attend the Yoga class held on Fridays.

There are fewer classes available during university holidays.

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 2
reading_texts.content:
Rules and Regulations for Members of Brightwood Leisure Centre

Membership allows individuals to use facilities subject to availability and centre rules.
Prices may change without notice.

The owners reserve the right to terminate membership for breaches of rules or offensive behaviour.

Members must inform staff of any illness or disability before using facilities.

Facilities are used at the member’s own risk.

The centre accepts no responsibility for loss or damage to personal property unless caused by staff negligence.

Cars must be parked correctly. The centre accepts no liability for loss or damage to vehicles.

Unclaimed property will be donated to charity after 28 days.

Questions 8–10

[This is a closed question set.
Question type: Multiple choice (single answer).
There are 3 questions (8–10).
Each question has four options (A–D).
Only ONE answer is correct.]

Members who upset other users of the leisure centre
A. will be reported to the Club Manager
B. will be given a warning
C. will have their membership cancelled
D. will be reported to the Membership Secretary

Membership may be put on hold
A. within fourteen days of joining
B. through arrangement with the manager
C. if the Membership Secretary agrees
D. in cases of injury only

Damage to members’ vehicles
A. is unlikely due to secure parking
B. will be paid for by the centre if it is their fault
C. is not the responsibility of the centre
D. may result from staff negligence

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 3
reading_texts.content:
Dressed for Work

Choosing what to wear at work can be difficult, particularly when starting a new job. Dressing too casually may give the impression that you are not taking your role seriously, while dressing too formally can make colleagues think you are unapproachable.

If possible, check the dress code after being offered a position. When attending interviews, observe what other employees are wearing.

For men, dark trousers, shoes and a simple shirt are generally acceptable. Wearing a tie on the first day is fine, but it may be unnecessary if no one else is wearing one.

For women, expectations vary widely, so observing colleagues in similar roles is often the best guide.

In many countries, especially in large corporations, there has been a move towards stricter dress codes, including uniforms for management.

Additional advice includes choosing conservative colours, avoiding large jewellery, maintaining good hygiene, and avoiding clothing with obvious designer logos.

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 4
reading_texts.content:
Salary Negotiation and Workplace Development

Successful salary negotiations require preparation. Many employees accept the first offer without researching what others in similar roles earn.

Negotiations should not focus solely on salary. Other benefits such as flexible hours or additional leave may also be discussed.

It is important not to take rejection personally. If negotiations fail, remain professional and move on gracefully, as maintaining positive relationships is essential and you never want to burn bridges.

Questions 15–20

[This is a closed question set.
Question type: TRUE / FALSE / NOT GIVEN.
There are 6 questions (15–20).
Answer options must be displayed as: TRUE, FALSE, NOT GIVEN.]

A mistake equally common across all types of employee is the premature acceptance of the first salary offer.

Employees can become demoralised despite receiving a pay rise.

Many people are unsuccessful in salary negotiations because of poor research.

It is important to clearly state the expected pay rise at the beginning of negotiations.

A negotiation could include discussion of benefits other than salary.

You should avoid salary negotiations when the employment market is weak.

Questions 21–27

[This is a closed question set.
Question type: TRUE / FALSE / NOT GIVEN.
There are 7 questions (21–27).
Answer options must be displayed as: TRUE, FALSE, NOT GIVEN.
All questions refer to Reading Text 4 only.]

Training and development programmes are usually created after weaknesses are identified.

Staff training always leads directly to promotion.

Companies prefer to recruit new employees rather than train existing staff.

Staff morale may improve as a result of training.

Customer service training is often overlooked.

Training employees to work with people from different cultural backgrounds benefits organisations more than many realise.

Employees should avoid maintaining contact with employers after unsuccessful negotiations.

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 5
reading_texts.content:
DWARF PLANET

The Discovery, Classification and Exploration of Pluto

A: On the 14th of July, 2015, a NASA deep space probe called New Horizons flew through the Pluto system in the Kuiper belt, located almost 6 billion kilometres from our sun, gathering high resolution photographs of the dwarf planet and its moons. Scientifically, the aims of the New Horizons mission were to provide experts on Earth with greater detail regarding the geomorphology, atmosphere, magnetosphere and surface composition of Pluto. As well as cameras for high resolution imagery, the spacecraft used an array of on-board scientific equipment to obtain information, including remote sensors, radio transmitters, computer subsystems, a large satellite dish and a radioisotope thermoelectric generator.

B: Pluto was discovered in February, 1930, by the American Charles Tombaugh, a young self-taught astronomer working at the Lowell Observatory in Arizona. Tombaugh, then in his early twenties, detected the existence of the planet by examining anomalies in photographic plates with the aid of a special viewing apparatus known as a blink microscope. His discovery soon made worldwide news headlines, and on the 25th of May, 1930, the members of the Lowell Observatory chose the name of Pluto for the ninth planet in the Solar System by unanimous vote. The name itself comes from that of the Roman god of the underworld, and was suggested by a schoolgirl living in England, whose uncle, a retired university librarian, had passed on her suggestion through academic acquaintances. It has been rumoured that Pluto's discovery served as inspiration for Walt Disney's canine character of the same name. There is, however, no question surrounding the naming of the element plutonium, which was named after the planet following the creation of the former by a team of scientists at the University of California in the early 1940s.

C: The estimated mass of Pluto was steadily revised downwards in the decades following its discovery, and was not accurately calculated until 1978, the same year in which Charon, the largest of the planet's five moons, was discovered by the United States Naval Observatory astronomer James Christy. While the original estimate of Pluto's mass had been seven times that of Earth, Christy and his colleague, Robert Harrington, compared Charon's orbital period and size with those of Pluto, estimating the planet's mass to be approximately 0.2 per cent that of the earth. A pair of smaller satellites, Nix and Hydra, was subsequently identified in 2005, with the final two of Pluto's known moons, named Kerberos and Styx, being discovered in 2011 and 2012 respectively.

D: However, in spite of having been regarded as the ninth planet in the solar system for more than fifty years, Pluto's status and classification began to come into question towards the close of the twentieth century. Initially, this was due to the fact that during the nineties a number of objects, made of rock and ice and of a similar size to Pluto, were discovered lying within the Kuiper belt, a circumstellar disc, in many ways resembling a gigantic asteroid belt, at the edge of the Solar System beyond Neptune. The first of these new Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs) was identified in 1992 by a pair of astronomers, David Jewitt and Jane Luu, working out of the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii. Many more Kuiper Belt Objects were found in the years that followed, making Pluto's official status as a planet increasingly controversial among many in the scientific community. While Pluto remains, at present, the largest of the known trans-Neptunian objects located in the Kuiper belt, the discovery in 2005 of a minor planet with a greater mass, Eris, in an outlying region of the Kuiper belt known as the scattered disc, prompted the International Astronomical Union (IAU) to create a formal definition of the term "planet" that excluded Pluto.

E: When the New Horizons interplanetary space probe was launched from Cape Canaveral in January, 2006, its primary mission was to voyage to Pluto, at that time the only remaining unexplored planet in the Solar System. However, in August of the same year, at the General Assembly of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) held in the Czech Republic, Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet on account of the fact that it did not meet one of the three formal conditions required to be classed as a planet. According to the official definition of the IAU, a planet must be in orbit around the sun and have sufficient mass both for its own gravity to make it spherical in shape and to have cleared the area around its orbit of smaller objects. Failing to meet the third of these criteria, Pluto was classified as a "dwarf planet". While the decision of the IAU to reduce the number of planets in the Solar System from nine to eight has received its fair share of both praise and criticism, the definition of Pluto as a dwarf planet, while controversial, remains in use. Today, there are five known bodies in the Solar System that have been recognised by the IAU as dwarf planets. In addition to Pluto, these are Ceres, Haumea, Makemake and Eris. At the same time, it has been estimated that there may be hundreds more as yet undiscovered and unclassified dwarf planets throughout the Solar System.

F: The high resolution images of Pluto made during the New Horizons close flyby of the planet and beamed back to Earth from across the Solar System have revealed a unique terrain. Far from being a flat, dead world, the rocky dwarf planet's surface contains a multitude of varied, complex landscapes, ranging from oddly-textured ridges with the appearance of tree bark or dragon scales, ice cliffs, valleys and mountains and frozen lakes and oceans to heavily cratered and pitted plains. Experts theorise that, in addition to the impact of other space bodies colliding with the planet, the majority of its terrain has been shaped by a combination of ice sublimation and tectonic forces. While still awaiting official approval from the International Astronomical Union, names for a number of Pluto's regions and topographical features have already been proposed by the New Horizons discovery team in consultation with the general public, including Tombaugh Regio, the Brass Knuckles, Tartarus Dorsa and Cthulhu Regio, the latter named after a fictional deity from the works of American author H.P. Lovecraft.

G: Irrespective of its official present classification as a dwarf planet, the New Horizons reconnaissance of Pluto provides a wealth of knowledge and data regarding the last major body in the Solar System not previously visited by a space probe. While the planet, spacecraft and New Horizons team may be comparatively small, the mission to the Pluto system not only represents the culmination of more than a decade's worth of preparation on Earth, but also the beginning of a new chapter in space exploration at the edge of the Solar System and beyond.
